what: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: package companion R package Book ” Basic Advanced Psychometrics R” [work Progress] package includes data-frames interesting functions create publication-friendly summary tables factor analysis, confirmatory factor analysis item analysis.

title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: can install stable version CRAN can install development version tabledown GitHub :

what: Creating Publication Ready Plots for Item Response Theory (IRT) Models.
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: IRT analysis highly depended visual representation model parameters. mirt package provides lots useful functions conduct IRT analysis. tabledown package offers ggplot2 based plotting options using mirt package based model parameters facilitate customization plots. Let’s create APA publication focused ggplot theme plots: used FFMQ.CFA data frame demo-validation data Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire. used mirt package run unidimensional IRT model. Let’s create item response theory based plots know test information. item characteristic, item information reliability curve.
code: library(ggplot2) #Creating a custom theme to be used for the plots apatheme=theme_bw()+   theme(panel.grid.major=element_blank(),         panel.grid.minor=element_blank(),         panel.background=element_blank(),         axis.text.x=element_text(size=10),         axis.text.y=element_text(size=10),         axis.title.x=element_text(size=10),         axis.title.y=element_text(size=10),         plot.title=element_text(siz=10),         legend.text=element_text(size=10),         legend.title=element_blank(),         axis.line.x=element_line(color='black'),         axis.line.y=element_line(color='black'),         panel.border=element_rect(color="black",                                     fill=NA,                                     size=1)) #Load the data data <- tabledown::FFMQ.CFA %>% dplyr::select(item1, item6, item11, item15, item20, item26, item31, item36) #Conduct the IRT analysis using mirt package  model <- mirt::mirt(data, model=1, itemtype='graded',                      SE=TRUE, Se.type ='MHRM',                     technical=list(NCYCLES=10000))

previous_headings: Examples > Creating Publication Ready Plots for Item Response Theory (IRT) Models.
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: tabledown offers ggicc function create ggplot2 based Item Characteristic Curve. ggicc function takes three arguments () model: IRT model (B) item number (C) Theta range: ggicc use symmetric theta range. Theta = 6 plot ICC theta range -6 6.

previous_headings: Examples > Creating Publication Ready Plots for Item Response Theory (IRT) Models.
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: tabledown offers ggiteminfo function create ggplot2 based item information curve. arguments ggiteminfo similar arguments ofggicc function

previous_headings: Examples > Creating Publication Ready Plots for Item Response Theory (IRT) Models.
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: tabledown also offers ggitestinfo ggitestinfo_se function create ggplot2 based test information curve. ggitestinfo_se give test information plot standard error measurement. arguments ggiteminfo similar arguments ofggicc function
code: tic <- tabledown::ggtestinfo_se(data, model)+labs(title="Test Information Curve")+geom_area(fill="blue", alpha=.5)+apatheme

previous_headings: Examples > Creating Publication Ready Plots for Item Response Theory (IRT) Models.
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: Using ggreliability function reliability curve can easily developed.

what: Creating A Summary Table for Factor Analysis
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: Commonly difficult create publication friendly table summaries necessary information factor analysis. example help pursuit help fac.tab() function
code: library(tabledown) library(tidyverse) library(psych) library(papaja)  Load the data from tabledown package data <- tabledown::Rotter[, 11:31]  Create a correlational matrix to compute factor analysis correlations <- psych::polychoric(data, correct=0)  fa.5F.1 <- psych::fa(r=correlations$rho, nfactors=5, fm="pa",rotate="varimax", residuals=TRUE, SMC=TRUE, n.obs =428)   table <- tabledown::fac.tab(fa.5F.1, .3, complexity = F)  papaja::apa_table(table, caption="A Beautiful Table describing the Fator analysis Output ")

what: Creating A Summary Table of Fit indices in Confirmatory Factor Analysis
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: reporting confirmatory factor analysis results, modern psychometrics suggest fitting several possible structural models latent construct reporting fit indices .  lavaan package fantastic job confirmatory factor analysis. see create publication friendly summary fit indices several fitted models using cfa.tab.multi() function.
code: {Load required packages} library(tabledown) library(tidyverse) library(lavaan) library(papaja)  load the data data <- tabledown::FFMQ.CFA   First CFA model  FF.model.Original <-  "Observe =~ item1 + item6 + item11 + item15 +item20 + item26 + item31 + item 36 Describe =~ item2 + item7 + Ritem12 + Ritem16 + Ritem22 + item27 + item32 + item37 Awareness =~ Ritem5 + Ritem8 + Ritem13 + Ritem18 + Ritem23 + Ritem28 + Ritem34 + Ritem38 Nonjudge =~ Ritem3 + Ritem10 + Ritem14 + Ritem17 + Ritem25 + Ritem30+ Ritem35 + Ritem39 Nonreact =~ item4 + item9 + item19 + item21 + item24 + item29 + item33 "  fit.original <- lavaan::cfa(FF.model.Original, data=data, estimator="MLR", mimic="Mplus")   Second CFA Model FF.model.Cor <-  "Observe =~ item1 + item6 + item11 + item15 +item20 + item26 + item31 + item 36 Describe =~ item2 + item7   + item27 + item32 + item37 Awareness =~ Ritem5 + Ritem8 + Ritem13 + Ritem18 + Ritem23 +Ritem28 + Ritem34 Nonjudge =~  Ritem10 + Ritem14 + Ritem25 + Ritem30+ Ritem35 Nonreact =~ item4 + item9 + item19 + item21 + item24 + item29 + item33 Ritem28 ~~ Ritem34 Ritem23 ~~ Ritem34" fit.Cor <- lavaan::cfa(FF.model.Cor, data = data, estimator = "MLR", mimic = "Mplus")   Third CFA Model  FF.short <- "Observe =~ item36 + item26 +item20 + item11 Describe =~ item2 + item7 + item27 +  item32 Awareness =~  Ritem8 + Ritem13 + Ritem23 + Ritem28 Nonjudge =~ Ritem10  + Ritem25 + Ritem30 + Ritem35 Nonreact =~ item9 + item19 + item21 + item24"  fit.short <- lavaan::cfa(FF.short, data=data, estimator="MLR", mimic="Mplus")  # Creating Summary table of fit indices from three fitted model (lavaan class objects)  table <- cfa.tab.multi(fit.original, fit.Cor, fit.short, robust= TRUE)  papaja::apa_table(table, caption="A Beautiful Table describing the Fit Indices of Three Fitted Model")

what: Creating Summary Table for Item Analysis
title: Create Publication Quality Tables and Plots
text: psychometrics conducting item-analysis common.  psych packages provided enough tools run item analysis smoothly. create publication friendly summary table item analysis necessary information using function des.tab()
code: library(tabledown)   library(tidyverse)   library(psych)  data <- tabledown::Rotter[, 11:31]   table <- des.tab(data) papaja::apa_table(table, caption="A Beautiful Table Summarizing the Output of Item Analysis")

what: A Function for calculating time spent in bed. — bedTime
title: A Function for calculating time spent in bed. — bedTime
text: function help calculate time person spent bed based sleep log. type calculation common sleep research. However, one can guess, working dates R bit tricky. function ease task. importantly  require entry dates calculate bed time. Just wake time time go bed enough (24 hour format).

title: A Function for calculating time spent in bed. — bedTime
A Function for calculating time spent in bed. — bedTime
text: x vector containing time bed. y vector containing time wake.

title: A Function for calculating time spent in bed. — bedTime
text: Calculates time spent bed hours. Output class numeric.

title: A Function for calculating time spent in bed. — bedTime
code: #Please use 24 hour format. #Easiest way is to enter the data as character. bed <-c("20:00", "21:00", "23:00") wake <-c("6:00", "7:00", "8:00") bedtime <- bedTime(bed, wake)

text: x lavaan class object. robust TRUE, provide robust fit indices applicable instead default indices.

what: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Tables with CFA fit indices from several lavaan objects. — cfa.tab.multi
title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Tables with CFA fit indices from several lavaan objects. — cfa.tab.multi
text: Often researchers required show fit indices several CFA models. function create publication worthy tables CFA fit indices several lavaan class objects. #' run function successfully one need provide least two lavaan  objects. command supports -five lavaan models.

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Tables with CFA fit indices from several lavaan objects. — cfa.tab.multi
code: cfa.tab.multi(x, y, z = NULL, a = NULL, b = NULL, robust = FALSE)

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Tables with CFA fit indices from several lavaan objects. — cfa.tab.multi
text: x first object class lavaan (Mandatory). y second object class lavaan (Mandatory). z third object class lavaan (Optional). fourth object class lavaan (Optional). b fifth object class lavaan (Optional). robust TRUE, provide robust fit indices applicable instead default indices.

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Factor Tables. — fac.tab
A Function for Creating Publication Quality Factor Tables. — fac.tab
text: x psych package object. cut value factor loading suppressed. complexity add complexity parameters.

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Factor Tables. — fac.tab
text: publication ready summary table Factor analysis conducted psych Package. Output structure data frame.

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Factor Tables. — fac.tab
code: data <- tabledown::Rotter[, 11:31] correlations <- psych::polychoric(data, correct = 0) fa.5F.1 <- psych::fa(r=correlations$rho, nfactors = 5, fm= "pa",rotate ="varimax", residuals = TRUE, SMC = TRUE, n.obs =428) table <- fac.tab(fa.5F.1, .3) #> Joining with `by = join_by(item)` #always save the output into an object

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Item Response Theory based item characteristic plot. — ggicc
A Function for Creating Publication Quality Item Response Theory based item characteristic plot. — ggicc
text: model mirt package fitted object. item Item number (.e. 1,2,3,4). theta Theta range. Put one number. Theta =3 considered theta range (-3 3).

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Item Response Theory based item characteristic plot. — ggicc
text: publication quality item characteristic plot. Output object ggplot object.

title: A Function for Creating Publication Quality Item Response Theory based item characteristic plot. — ggicc
code: data <- tabledown::Rotter[, 11:31] model <- mirt::mirt(data, model = 1, itemtype = '2PL', SE = TRUE, Se.type = 'MHRM') #>  Iteration: 1, Log-Lik: -5444.747, Max-Change: 0.56424 Iteration: 2, Log-Lik: -5374.008, Max-Change: 0.30858 Iteration: 3, Log-Lik: -5357.722, Max-Change: 0.17532 Iteration: 4, Log-Lik: -5353.406, Max-Change: 0.09162 Iteration: 5, Log-Lik: -5352.045, Max-Change: 0.06068 Iteration: 6, Log-Lik: -5351.603, Max-Change: 0.03828 Iteration: 7, Log-Lik: -5351.412, Max-Change: 0.01627 Iteration: 8, Log-Lik: -5351.383, Max-Change: 0.01187 Iteration: 9, Log-Lik: -5351.371, Max-Change: 0.00751 Iteration: 10, Log-Lik: -5351.365, Max-Change: 0.00390 Iteration: 11, Log-Lik: -5351.364, Max-Change: 0.00344 Iteration: 12, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00026 Iteration: 13, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00024 Iteration: 14, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00109 Iteration: 15, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00081 Iteration: 16, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00031 Iteration: 17, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00011 Iteration: 18, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00054 Iteration: 19, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00012 Iteration: 20, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00035 Iteration: 21, Log-Lik: -5351.363, Max-Change: 0.00010 #>  #> Calculating information matrix...  plot <- tabledown::ggicc(model, 1, 3)

code: data <- tabledown::FFMQ.CFA[, c(9,10,12,14)] recode_code <- c( "1" = "Never or very rarely true", "2" = "Rarely true", "3"= "Sometimes true","4" = "Often true","5" = "Very often or always true") sample_tab <- gt_tab(data,recode_code)

what: Produce Publication Quality Tables and Plots — tabledown
title: Produce Publication Quality Tables and Plots — tabledown
text: tabledown package provides necessary data frames used throughout book neat functions.

title: Produce Publication Quality Tables and Plots — tabledown
text: Rotter: Psychometric validation data Bangla Rotter's Internal- External Scale. Gantt Spot: Two sample data-frames creating project management Gantt chart. FFMQ.CFA: Structural Validation data Bangla Five Factor Mindfulness Questionnaire. FFMQ.Val:Correlational Validity evidences Bangla Five Factor Mindfulness Questionnaire.

title: Produce Publication Quality Tables and Plots — tabledown
text: packages includes neat useful functions create tables figures suitable journal submission: fac.tab(): Creates publication ready table output "psych"  package based factor analysis. des.tab(): Creates publication ready descriptive table Item analysis reporting normality assumptions. normality.loop(): Compute normality test whole data frame. grouping variable required. bedTime(): Calculate total time spent bed sleep log entry. cfa.tab():Creates table necessary fit indices "lavaan" class objects. cfa.tab/multi():creates table necessary fit indices several lavaan class objects. ggicc: Creates ggplot2 based publication ready Item Characteristics Curve "mirt" package based item response theory estimations. ggiteminfo: Creates ggplot2 based publication ready Item Information Curve "mirt" package based item response theory estimations. ggtestinfo: Creates ggplot2 based publication ready Test Information Curve "mirt" package based item response theory estimations. ggtestinfo_se: Creates ggplot2 based publication ready Test Information Curve standard error "mirt" package based item response theory estimations. advisable load tidyverse along tabledown
